awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Extension of a Dendrochronological Sequence to northern Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
Drs. Paula Turkon, Sturt Manning, and Carol Griggs, along with colleagues from Mexico, will conduct research to provide a high-resolution absolute tree-ring chronology for Northern Mesoamerican archaeological sites using a combination of tree-ring and AMS radiocarbon data.  This project extends their preliminary research both geographically and chronologically, with the goal of linking the existing Epiclassic chronology from Northwestern Mesoamerica that ends in the 8th century A.D., to the regionally extensive, calendar-dated chronologies from living and relic trees in the same region. The dendrochronological results will offer dating precision to archaeologists working in these regions for time periods that do not have written sources of chronological data. It will also establish the foundation for climate reconstruction studies that, in the future, will help clarify the long-term relationships between the magnitude of climatic change and human response. In fostering close collaboration between archaeologists, dendrochronologists, graduate, and undergraduate students from multiple institutions throughout Mexico and the United States, this project's mission is to encourage the application of dendroarchaeology [=archaeological dendrochronology], currently not part of archaeological fieldwork or analysis in Mexico. 

Mesoamerican archaeologists have long acknowledged the need for precise dating methods in order to understand cultural change, particularly in the region north of the core of Mesoamerican culture. Yet despite tremendous success in the development of tree-ring dating of archaeological sites just north in the American Southwest, and the more recent development of long tree-ring chronologies in Mexico that cover the past 1300 years, dendroarchaeology has been virtually absent in Mesoamerica. The first stage of this NSF funded project demonstrated the availability, measurability, and similarities in growth patterns ("crossdatability") of archaeological tree-ring samples in Northwestern Mesoamerica from the 5th to 8th centuries A.D.  In this second stage, the researchers will incorporate archaeological samples from Postclassic and historic sites located in a broader geographic region in northern Mesoamerica. Because the new archaeological collections of wood will likewise be from a time period for which there are no well-established master chronologies, the tree-ring sequences produced from the prehispanic sites will be initially anchored in time by "radiocarbon wiggle-matching."   This method fits a known relative sequence of radiocarbon dates from specific tree-rings against the radiocarbon calibration curve to achieve a precise fit and thus calendar placement with minimal error.  Ultimately, we intend to create a continuous tree-ring record from the present back to the Classic period, using both the archaeological and historic collections, as well as existing calendar-dated chronologies.  The resulting data will not only fill a significant gap in our knowledge of the chronology of Northern Mesoamerica, but help address broader questions such as the rate, timing, and directionality of cultural influences with the Mesoamerican cultural core. Since dendroarchaeological methods are cumulative and iterative, the chronologies will gain in length, sample depth, and robustness, and will become increasingly useful to archaeologists working in broader geographic regions and time periods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to begin to try to construct a tree-ring record for northwestern Mexico (Mesoamerica) that would fill the gap in existing knowledge between tree-ring series from forest trees and modern sites in this region that reaches back to about the 17th century CE and a rich prehistoric archaeological record in this same region ending around the 8th century CE. The approaches to achieve this goal used a combination of dendrochronological methods—the study of tree-rings and investigating and identifying the co-varying patterns of tree-ring growth over time of the same species in a given region—and the use of tree-ring sequenced radiocarbon (14C) dating (so-called ‘wiggle-matching’) to help approximately place otherwise floating tree-ring series in calendar time so we could start to see which tree-ring records, and which sites producing these, might offer evidence for which periods between, overall, the 5th century CE and the 20th century CE (an example is shown in the Image). The wood samples examined came from fieldwork and investigation of various historic structures and from archaeological sites in northwestern Mexico thought by experts and excavators to date approximately within the period from the 5th-20th centuries CE. The key intellectual merit reason for trying to construct such tree-ring chronologies for the different tree species employed by humans is because this would then enable precise and accurate dating of many of the wood remains incorporated into structures and other objects—previously not possible—which would greatly facilitate archaeological and historical analysis. The broader impacts of this work are twofold. First, it will inform and allow a better (accurate) history of human activities in this region. Second, once a longer tree-ring record is created, this will then provide an important resource for climate history and analysis, since the tree rings, both in terms of their changing annual ring-widths and the annually-resolved stable isotope record preserved in their cellulose, will inform on the climate conditions pertaining when the trees were growing. Achieving such complete long tree-ring chronologies from the several tree-species in the region that produce visible annual growth increments (tree-rings) suitable for the application of dendrochronological methods is a long-term aim that will take a number of years. This project, within the available time and resources, was able to make god progress, locating and placing a number of tree-ring sequences from historic and archaeological sites variously dating from the 5th to the 20th centuries CE. These begin to fill and inform several parts of previous gaps in time, and these findings and data demonstrate the potential of dendrochronology to provide a dating resource and potential climate history archive for a culturally and geographically important region immediately adjacent and relevant to the southwest USA.


Last Modified: 09/17/2023
Modified by: Sturt W Manning

Image
  • Example of this project's combining of tree-ring (dendrochronological) information with radiocarbon dating to achieve a so-called 'wiggle-match' near-absolute calendar placement of a tree-ring series ELC-1 (here showing dating of the last extant tree-ring of this sample, Relative Year, RY, 1161).
    Sturt Manning
    Sturt W Manning
    ELC-1 wiggle-match placement
